Surely there would be some improvements in those departments, especially with a bigger budget. `New Moon' just reeks with failure; you need a mop and bucket to clean it all up. I would love to point out a few good points, but since there are more bad than good we will save them to play redeeming qualities. First of all the script...it was as if it was written by a first grade English class. The dialogue was so cheesy and pathetic I was throwing up inside of my mouth at points. Now that there are werewolves in the film you think they could make them look a little more real. Well, I have to say the wolves looked pretty life like but the transformation looked cartoonish. Take a look at a film like `The Incredible Hulk' Edward Nortans transformation looked much more real and believable than these werewolves. Now here is the part that really pissed me off. Dakota Fanning and Michael Sheen did a fantastic acting job and Dakota finally put that creepy face of hers to good use. reviewText: I'd give New Moon 3.5 stars if I properly could but I liked it more than not, hence the 4 star rating. I've read every Twilight book and found them to be entertaining enough. reviewText: I liked the first movie in this series. It had some great action scenes, head-butting personality conflicts, and tolerable myth-making, in addition to its teen-appeal factors. Despite what I had heard about this one, its predecessor got my hopes up.You have to realize, though, that I'm not in this movie's target demographic. I'm A) male and B) over 16, so I might not even have a right to an opinion. This movie pretty much skipped all the things I liked in the previous one, and replaced it with adolescent moping, emotional tilt-a-whirl, and concern over the ineffectual lead girl getting the right boy. I appreciate the fact that girls need movies too, and generally seem to be an under-served clientele. Based on the cheering that broke out at all the mushy moments, this flick seemed to say what it wanted to the people it wanted to say it to.I'm just not one of those people. I assign a star rating based on my own experience of this movie. I expect everyone in the theater with me (except maybe some tolerant fathers chaperoning their little gaggle) to rate it differently.-- wiredweird

reviewText: I have read all the books in the series and frankly felt New Moon was the weakest (my favorite is Eclipse). I wasn't sure how Chris Weitz was going to adapt the book for the big screen but it exceeded my expectations. I usually prefer the books to the movie adaptations but in this case, I actually preferred the movie. New Moon sees Bella Swan (Kristen Stewart) turning 18, and she's none too pleased about it because Edward (Robert Pattinson) is 17 and will remain forever so since he is an immortal. The fact that she's now older than Edward troubles her and Bella feels the only way to get past this is by becoming a vampire herself. Edward will have none of it as he does not wish her soul damned. So to cut a long story short - Edward breaks up with Bella and leaves Forks (the town where they live) together with the Cullens (his family). Bella sinks into a great depression, one which only 16-year-old Jacob (Taylor Lautner)is able to help her through.Bella realizes that though Edward is physically gone, they share a strong psychic connection as Edward seems to sense when Bella is in danger and pops up as a sort of vision to warn her off. This compels Bella to indulge in risky endeavors such as approaching strange men, going on a bike ride, and even cliff diving. There's also a very real threat from renegade vampire Victoria who is bent on killing Bella. In the meantime, Jacob goes through some personal issues as he is compelled to become part of a pack on the reservation. Little does Bella suspect the true nature of this 'pack' until much later, and this has important repercussions on their friendship and future dealings with the Cullens.I felt this second installment was a vast improvement over "Twilight" - firstly, the acting is much more credible and natural. Kirsten Stewart has made Bella more than just a cardboard character, and unlike the character of Bella in the books, here viewers get to see how Bella processes things and emotes, unlike the books. Taylor Lautner was the most compelling actor in this movie - he credibly portrays his anguish at not being able to get Bella to love him as she does Edward, and at the same time, his confusion over his new role and identity. There's not much of Robert Pattinson's Edward in this installment, though the scenes he appears in are quite well-done (he just seems to flinch so much that I found it quite annoying to be honest). The other secondary characters are all there as in the first and do a good job in their respective roles.The cinematography is excellent, effectively capturing the ethereal beauty of Forks with its magnificent forests and coastline, as well as the beauty of the Italian countryside (when Alice and Bella go to see the Volturi). The special effects were amazing - the transformation from human to werewolf, and the scenes where Victoria is hunting and trying to evade capture by the werewolves are all credibly done (even my husband who is not into the series loved it). All in all, I felt director Chris Weitz has done a good job in adapting the book to the big screen and I can't wait for his interpretation of Eclipse!
